Key Arguments: The proposed legislation is vague and broad in scope.
Freedom of speech is a fundamental right under Common Law and should not be restricted.
The bill is incompatible with Australia's international human rights treaty obligations.
The legislation could lead to arbitrary restriction and silencing of free speech.
There are no mechanisms for accountability or for affected parties to have grievances heard.
Foreign entities might ignore the bill, potentially penalizing those it aims to protect.
Notable Quotes: We have the ability to think and speak for ourselves and freedom of speech is a fundamental right under Common Law.
My concern with this Bill is that it will allow the government to arbitrarily restrict and potentially even silence free speech.
Censorship needs to be replaced by transparency with full accountability being determined within our shores.
